mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Source and Composition of Glacier Dissolved Organic Matter

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Mountain glaciers export ancient, energy-rich, and highly bioavailable dissolved organic matter (DOM) to freshwater and marine ecosystems, influencing downstream carbon cycling and supporting food webs. Despite its importance and the sensitivity of mountain glaciers to climate change, the sources of organic matter (OM) underpinning glacier DOM composition and its high bioavailability remain poorly constrained. To date, our understanding of the glacier carbon cycle has been formed from a handful of glaciers in a small number of regions (typically Greenland, Alaska, and the High Mountains of Asia), where geographically disparate studies have yielded different conclusions as to the dominant source of glacier OM. For example, studies in Greenland have suggested glacier DOM is predominately microbial in origin, whereas studies based in Alaska and Tibet postulate DOM to be primarily atmospheric deposition-derived. Implicitly, these studies indicate there may be regional and global heterogeneity in glacier DOM source and composition, which would have implications for understanding the fate of glacier-derived DOM and the age of carbon respired across glacier-fed ecosystems. In this dissertation combined analytical approaches (including molecular-level and carbon isotopic techniques) are used to assess glacier DOM composition across regional and global gradients. We highlight the glacier DOM pool as a distinct and dynamic carbon pool in the global carbon cycle, with significant diversity in DOM source and composition at both intra-regional and global scales. By analyzing global variability in composition across 136 glacier outflows covering six continents, we demonstrate glacier DOM is regionally distinct, where its composition is largely determined by the relative contribution of OM from in situ production and atmospheric deposition. We combine molecular-level, and bulk and compound-specific black carbon isotopic analyses, to show that anthropogenic deposition (i.e., fossil fuel combustion byproducts) has impacted glacier carbon cycling at the global scale. Nonetheless, in regions downwind of industrial centers (e.g., Alaska) the glacier OM pool is likely older and more stable in composition compared to remote regions (e.g., Ecuador), where glacier DOM is likely predominately derived from in situ production. In glaciers dominated by in situ production, the DOM exported to downstream and marine ecosystems is likely younger in radiocarbon age and relatively more aliphatic (i.e., energy-rich). Using novel respiratory carbon recovery system experiments for a subset of glacier outflows in southeast Alaska, we conclude this modern, in situ produced OM, may underpin the high bioavailability of the glacier dissolved organic carbon (DOC) pool. Thus, although globally glacier DOC is ancient and bioavailable, a modern pool of OM may underpin its high bioavailability. Together, these findings have wide ranging implications for how we contextualize the glacier carbon cycle and the role of glacier-derived DOC in downstream ecosystems.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Carbon Cycle, Cryosphere, Dissolved Organic Matter, FT-ICR MS, Glaciers, Radiocarbon
Robert G. M. Spencer, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sarah Lester, University Representative; Jeff Chanton, Committee Member; Eran Hood, Committee Member; Olivia Mason, Committee Member.
